reviewText:
This game has my seal of approval.

I love how much effort they put into all the details, even if the whole game was clearly made on a budget, you can tell they tried hard to make it feel as feature inclusive and fun as possible.

$4 game has:

- Very good boat physics
- Fun, challenging racing
- Boat upgrades (paint, speed, sponsors, etc)
- Open world to navigate
- Non-racing ways to earn money (taxi people, look for treasure, etc)
- LAN multiplayer!
- Arcade and career modes
- Radio station with generic but interesting music loaded into it
- Very nice water graphics, including the boat wake" looks pretty slick

I've only just started to play
date: but I've got a good sense of what this game has to offer.  For the price
hoursPlayed: I expected it to be a stinker but it is actually fun to play.  You start off your career with a rusty slow boat and no money and have many ways to earn it.  Racing was too hard right off the bat so I did some taxi runs
voteText:
then discovered this pirate treasure mode where they just literally scatter the world with money and you just have to collect it all.  Well since there was only a couple of upgrades on the rusty boat I maxed it out and now need to figure out how to get a better one.

Some negative aspects I would say is the limited selection of upgrades on the boat classes.  Maybe things get deep down the road but if the later boats have just one speed and one rudder upgrade I would be disapointed.  Time will tell though as I venture through this title.

As far as graphics options and settings
helpfulPercent: this game is fully loaded.  All resolution
column17: etc is all here in the launcher.  Everything worked on the first try as well
column18: no crashing or hiccups.  In the game
column19: it looks beautiful but the textures are a bit too low-resolution to be a game from 2015 however
column20: they should work on that as the whole experience would be improved with textures many times larger.\n\n360 controller works out of the box
column21: but there is a chance it needs to be turned on before launching the game and selected in the launcher as the input device
column22: but I can say that you can use both the keyboard and controller for at least navigating menus at the same time
column23:
which is nice.

Wishlist:
- Trading cards
- Achievements
- Steam Cloud
- Online multiplayer
- Higher resolution textures

Overall totally worth the $4 it is currently."

reviewText:
I bought this game on impulse, because of the low pricetag and the inability to resist. I have to say, I'm positively surprised by what I got. Note that this game was originally released in 2008 (according to the official website) It made it's way through Greenlight and was released on Steam this week.
It's an open world boat racing game, wich takes place in 3 area's. You start in Russia and move on to Greece and the Caribbean later. You can also quicktravel between the various locations in the game, once you unlocked them. You navigate to various point on the map to start races, taxi jobs, upgrade and reskin your boat or buy a new one, acquiring sponsors etc. You start your career with a crappy, slow and ugly boat. Races can be a bit dull in the beginning but with the various ways to make money in this game, you can quickly upgrade your boat or buy a new one. The upgrading ability is limited to just a button press for a better engine, to give an example. You can't choose between various parts. At least not where I am now in the game. While racing you can pickup powerups, like nitro or weapons to use against your opponents: rockets, torpedo's, shockwaves, mines, EMP's, oh and off course, bouncing, exploding frogs :)  So if you are looking for a realistic boat racing game, this isn't really your thing. Then there's a mode were you collect golden coins that are spread out over the map. So another way to make money.
Graphics and sound are decent. Again, considering the pricetag, I'm just satisfied with it. Just don't expect super high resolution textures or cool lighting and particle effects. For some strange reason, the screen ratio in the menu's is 4:3. At least, on my system. However, ingame it all works with the proper resolution and screen ratio that you can configure in the game's launcher. You can set more graphics and sound options there.
I like the game's physics too. They are not hardcore offcourse but certainly not too arcady. The boats really have some weight to them.
The game has 'experimental' controller support but at this moment, you are better of with just the keyboard, wich actually works fine. The 360 controller does work. However, you can't remap the buttons and the layout is a bit odd and unusual. Gas, brake and steering is all done with the left thumb stick. The triggers don't do anything with the boats. I hope the dev will add the ability to remap the buttons in a future update. It's not a huge letdown. Like I said, the keyboard works fine too.
All in all, I'm very satisfied with this game, which costs the same as a cup of coffee and a snack. You really can't go wrong with that.

reviewText: A great little boat racing game. It can take some time to get used to driving the lakes. But once you get used to the driving you will have a lot of fun with this game. The game works great with Eyefinity and Surround setups. The music in game is pumping and fun to listen to. The graphics are well done. This racing game is fun for people of all ages. Recommended!

reviewText: Let me tell you a little story about my father. He was the boating king of Lake Tohochobee. One fateful day, while we were on his boat, he says to me: Son. One fateful day you're going to inherit my crown. You will become a boating king." Without even looking up from my gameboy
date: I murmured "that's great". Then something horrible happened. An Arabian Sea Bear burst out of the water
hoursPlayed: and pulled him overboard. Then he was bitten by a snake
votesFunny: and then he lost his wallet.  The very next day I swore that I would avenge him. I packed my bags
column16: and drove to Russia. This is how the story of PepsimanVsJoe: Boating Legend began.\n\nNow if you believed that story
column17: I have an even better one for you. It's about how I got the name "PepsimanVsJoe". It involves Gabe Newell and a Riverboat Casino.\n\nSeriously though
column18: I can't deny the appeal of cruising in a motorboat. Unfortunately
column19: I'm a poor geek who can barely afford his car. Once again I have to rely on videogames. Luckily
column20: there's at least one out there that attempts to capture this great experience: Aquadelic GT. This is an open-world game where you can travel to multiple locations
column23: and even enjoy some leisurely activities (like hunting for treasure or rescuing flood victims).\n\nAfter choosing your hideous and poorly-dressed avatar
column24: you start off in Russia with a tin-can of a boat. Driving is very fluid
column25: and it captures the right balance between simulation and arcade. The controls take some adjusting
column26: especially if you're using a 360 pad. The throttle is on the same stick as the steering! If anything
column27: the throttle should be on the right stick. Alas
column28: there's no in-game option to change the controls
column29: you'll have to use some third-party software. Otherwise
column30: getting around is well-done.\n\nNow if you want to make some real money
column31: you have to race. This is where Aquadelic GT goes over the deep-end. Now I've watched exactly zero boat races
column32: unless you count the John Candy movie Summer Rental. However. that movie ended with a sailing race
column34: the point is that the races in this game are basically Mario Kart. Each track is comprised of multiple check-points
column35: with various weapon-crates and nitrous power-ups sprinkled about. These weapons include torpedoes
column41: but also pretty unbalanced.\n\nAll too often
column43: of not having a solution for the racers that break away from the pack. While everyone is blowing each other up
column44: the one guy that manages to escape the chaos
column45: will pull way ahead and win without any trouble. Nintendo's answer to this quandary was the blue shell
column46: nobody likes the blue shell. Aquadelic GT has no blue shell or "realistic equivalent" to speak of. The racer in 1st has the highest chance of running into mines or nets
column47: but races typically only have two or three laps.\n\nI don't have an answer to this quandary
column48: but I will admit that despite this issue
column49: the races are still really fun. A well-timed explosive can send a number of boats spinning
column51: and possibly crashing into the shores. Collisions are also handled amusingly. Sometimes if an opponent is closing in as I'm about to make a turn
column52: I'll do a 90 degree turn while killing the throttle. This would probably cause a t-bone accident
column53: but instead it results in my opponent going over me and way off-track. The AI in this game is non-existent
column54: and usually all it takes is one good crash to put them out of the race. It's too bad that the only option for racing with humans is via LAN. Single-player races tend to be too one-sided.\n\nAside from the acquisition of necessary cash for new boats/upgrades
column55: races also lead to sponsorship deals. Basically
column56: sponsors add a flat multiplier bonus to your winnings & popularity. More popularity leads to better sponsors
column57: which leads to more...you get the idea. Sometimes having a sponsor will require that you take on a passenger. For awhile I had a guy dressed like a burger riding in a boat with me. Alright then. Winning races will also unlock new locations. Greece and the Caribbeans look quite nice
column58: for a low-budget game. There's a decent amount of atmosphere
column60: and there are even people hanging out. Just don't look closely
column61: as you'll surely notice that they don't move at all. It's a little unsettling
column62: but even major franchises like Gran Turismo and Forza skimp on the spectator graphics.\n\nAt 4.99
column63: this game will probably last you close to five hours. I might play some more races to see what sort of shenanigans I can cause
column64: or just cruise around while listening to Sweet Freedom. I've already unlocked every location
column66: and purchased the most expensive boat. I guess I could buy that dream home
column67: or get sponsored by the largest company
column68: but there's not really much else to do. Honestly
column69: I'm fine with that. Aquadelic GT does not wear out its welcome. While it never really excels at what it tries to do
column70: it still delivers an entertaining experience.\n\nIn short
column71: if the idea of driving a boat appeals to you
column72: and you're willing to overlook questionable controls and some head-scratching design-decisions
column73: you'll enjoy Aquadelic GT.\n\nIf you liked this review or want to see more recommended games
column74: be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group"

reviewText:
For the price this is totally Worth A Buy!

But do not expect many game modes or a long campaign/story (multiplayer i have not played)
instead expect a grind through the singleplayer with nice water details and boat feeling combined with weapons/boost + you can upgrade all boats (but beware some of them do not need better sterring)

ps. would easy had paid twice as much or more ^^
all i can say is that russian game developers need more confident and believe more in them self (you got the skillz)

reviewText: It's not too bad.  No way to configure controller though, which IS bad.  Perhaps someone can make a mod to do so, if the company refuses or can't. (just a thought.)
Very good arcade racer.\nWell worth the 5 bucks.

Oh my! I used to have a CD of this lying around ages ago and I picked it up immediately when it came up on Steam, because it was just a fiver.\n\nIt's a pleasant boat racing / freeroam cruising game with a lot of unlocks, a handful of pretty, visually distinct locations and a great chilled-out soundtrack. Don't expect anything amazing with that price tag. The game is a competent, pleasant little package nonetheless.

reviewText: I was expecting something between Water Race and Riptide GP, and instead I got some water racing where what matters the most is the weapon/nitro you pick up during racing. As Mario Kart or similar game, you can race as good as you want but you will still be wrecked by these bloody weapons. Not what I expected.
